data.title: The 5 Boroughs of New York City — Cool Hand Movers NYC
data.meta_description: All five boroughs of New York City feature eclectic neighborhoods and housing.
data.text:
New York City, or the "Big Apple," is one of the world's most iconic and diverse cities. NYC comprises five unique boroughs, each with stories to tell and communities to embrace. In this guide, we will walk you through the five boroughs of New York City: Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, The Bronx, and Staten Island.

NYC by the Borough

Manhattan: The Heart of The Big Apple

Manhattan, often regarded as the heart of New York City, may be the most iconic island in the country. Manhattan's elite constructed opulent mansions along Fifth Avenue during the Gilded Age. The 20th century brought the advent of skyscrapers and the beginnings of a world-renowned skyline.

Manhattan by the Numbers

Population: ~1.7 million

Household Income: $95,866

Employment: 62.5%

Home Ownership Rate: 24.3%

Source: US Census Bureau, Manhattan borough

Living in Manhattan Neighborhoods

Manhattan living is synonymous with a fast-paced urban lifestyle, but each neighborhood maintains a different atmosphere. The demand for luxury condominiums, green spaces, and sustainable living has shaped new residential developments. Still, conservation efforts preserve the charm of historic neighborhoods.

The Upper West Side features classic New York City architecture. Brownstone buildings share blocks with iconic residences like The Dakota.

The affluent "triangle-below-canal" Tribeca offers upscale penthouses with modern designs and panoramic views. This neighborhood draws celebrity renters and homeowners.

Trendy lofts exude artistic vibes on the Lower East Side, even as the area experiences change. It's a haven for artists and creative professionals who embrace, or at least don't mind, the active nightlife scene.

On the Upper East Side, elegant townhouses and pre-war co-op buildings provide a taste of classic New York City living. Residents here enjoy views of Central Park and the Museum Mile.

The Financial District (FiDi) has sleek, modern towers with state-of-the-art amenities. This neighborhood offers convenient living for professionals working in the financial sector. You’ll also see historic Dutch-style architecture and cobblestone streets.

Harlem offers a unique blend of historic charm and cultural vibrancy. You'll find elegant brownstones, townhouses, and lively apartment buildings. The neighborhood is famous for its role in the Harlem Renaissance.

Hell’s Kitchen, which borders Broadway from the west, hosts luxury high-rises amid vibrant entertainment and dining scenes.

Manhattan’s Hidden Gem

Located within Fort Tryon Park, The Cloisters is a unique treasure that transports visitors to medieval Europe. This Metropolitan Museum of Art branch houses an exceptional medieval art and architecture collection. Its cloistered gardens overlook the Hudson River and the New Jersey Palisades.

Moving to Manhattan

Cool Hand Movers provides invaluable tips and considerations for a smooth transition to living in Manhattan.

Brooklyn: A Blend of Culture and Community

With its direct connections to Manhattan, Queens, and Staten Island, Brooklyn is a cultural epicenter. The borough's distinct neighborhoods, from the historic brownstones of Park Slope to the artistic enclaves of Bushwick, make it a destination for residents and visitors alike. With a storied history, Brooklyn welcomes all who seek to immerse themselves in its vibrant atmosphere.

Brooklyn by the Numbers

Population: ~2.7 million

Household Income: $73,951

Employment: 59.9%

Home Ownership Rate: 29.5%

Source: US Census Bureau, Brooklyn borough

Living in Brooklyn Neighborhoods

Real estate in Brooklyn varies in price, with some expensive areas like DUMBO and Brooklyn Heights and more affordable neighborhoods like Bay Ridge and East New York. This variety allows for a range of lifestyle choices within the borough.

Famous for its charming, historic brownstones, Brooklyn Heights offers a glimpse of old New York architecture alongside upscale new construction and converted warehouses.

Fort Greene features beautiful brownstones, co-op buildings, and new developments with plenty of access to green space. It’s home to the Brooklyn Academy of Music and several independent bookstores.

Known for its vibrant art scene, Bushwick offers loft-style apartments, townhouses, and industrial-inspired living spaces.

Crown Heights has recently seen a flurry of new developments, but you can still find impeccably preserved Victorian-style homes in its North Historic District.

Greenpoint, the northernmost neighborhood of the borough, offers quiet days, flavorful food, and wood-frame houses.

Brooklyn’s Hidden Gem

Founded in 1838, Green-Wood Cemetery is a national historic landmark and a beautiful final resting place for notable figures, including Leonard Bernstein and Jean-Michel Basquiat. It borders South Slope, Windsor Terrace, and Sunset Park.

Moving to Brooklyn

Cool Hand Movers has you covered with expert advice on moving logistics and how we can simplify the process.

The Bronx: The Northernmost Borough

During the 19th century, the Bronx saw significant urban development. Elegant homes and Victorian-style buildings went up in areas like the Grand Concourse. In 1899, the Bronx Zoo opened its naturalistic animal habitats, the first of their kind in the U.S.. The borough's enormous green spaces have also lent themselves to state parks and the New York Botanical Gardens.

The borough that gave us rap music and salsa dancing is still brimming with culture and creativity. From the South Bronx to Van Cortlandt Park, you have plenty to discover in the only New York City borough not situated on an island.

In the historic neighborhood of St. George, you'll come across charming Colonial Revival homes. These residences boast gabled roofs and symmetrical façades, often featuring red brick exteriors. St. George also offers sleek condos.

Great Kills features a mix of spacious single-family homes and townhouses. Many waterfront properties boast contemporary designs, but you can also find traditional Colonial and Cape Cod-style houses.

You'll find a variety of home styles in this sought-after neighborhood of Tottenville. Look for cozy Cape Cod-style residences, spacious ranch houses, and even newer constructions with modern amenities.

Willowbrook offers a mix of housing options, including single-family homes and apartments. Many of the single-family dwellings follow traditional suburban designs and well-maintained lawns.

Stapleton features various apartment complexes, offering comfortable living spaces for renters. These complexes come in contemporary designs and provide convenient access to local amenities.

Staten Island’s Hidden Gem

Historic Richmond Town in Staten Island's Richmondtown neighborhood is a captivating living history village. Explore early American life through preserved historic homes, exhibits, and demonstrations. Reach it via the Staten Island Railway to Richmondtown station.

Moving to Staten Island

Are you planning your move to Staten Island? Cool Hand Movers will guide you through a smooth transition.

Queens: The Suburban Enclave

Queens, sometimes called the "World's Borough," has undergone a remarkable transformation throughout its history. With significant urban development in the early 20th century and its role as the host of the 1964 World's Fair, Queens has seen waves of change and progress. From its early days as a cluster of small towns to becoming a cornerstone of New York City life, Queens has evolved into a vibrant and multicultural hub.

Queens by the Numbers

Population: ~2.4 million

Household Income: $80,557

Employment: 60.1%

Home Ownership Rate: 68.7%

Source: US Census Bureau, Queens borough

Living in Queens Neighborhoods

Queens offers a balance of affordability and cultural vibrancy. Astoria and Long Island City tend toward higher rents due to their proximity to Manhattan and thriving local scenes, while neighborhoods like Jamaica and Flushing are more budget-friendly.

Astoria, a bustling neighborhood in western Queens, features a mix of historic townhouses and contemporary apartments. It's known for its diverse restaurants and East River views.

Flushing offers many housing options, including single-family homes, condos, and co-ops. Its bustling business district is a hub of activity.

A rapidly developing waterfront neighborhood, Long Island City features sleek high-rises with stunning Manhattan skyline views. It's a popular choice for young professionals.

With its tree-lined streets, Jackson Heights offers a blend of pre-war co-op buildings and garden apartment complexes. It's known for its cultural diversity and historic district.

Forest Hills is a residential neighborhood boasting Tudor-style homes, co-op apartments, and upscale condos. It's a family-friendly area with excellent schools.

Queens’ Hidden Gem

Visit the former Corona home of the jazz legend Louis Armstrong. Delve into the life and legacy of one of the greatest musicians of the 20th century.

Moving to Queens
